lcInstruction.p: In DITA, you use a conref to reuse pieces of content. These content pieces could be admonishments (notes, cautions, and warnings), boilerplate text (such as your company address), and more. For example, a product’s description could be set up as a conref so it is the same across all your documents.

Suppose you have the following note in a topic called location.dita:
lcInstruction.pre: <topic id="topicid"> ... <note id="whatduckslike">Ducks prefer lakes over deserts.</note> ... </topic>

Most DITA authoring tools streamline the process for inserting conref code, so you probably will not type the file path, topic ID, and so on, as shown in the example.
lcInstruction.note: The target element must be the same element type as the element that contains the conref attribute. Thus you can only conref a <note> element from another <note> element; you can only conref an <li> element from another <li> element, and so on.

It's a good practice to create separate topics that contain reusable elements, rather than just picking a random topic and pointing a conref to that topic. This helps you keep better tabs on the content that is reused and allows you to control when it changes.
